transcript.content: The Ricky Gervais show on Guardian Unlimited.
Hi, Ricky Gervais here with me, Stephen Murch.
Hello.
And Kyle Pilkington. Welcome to the final episode in our series of twelve podcasts. I say final, it's final of twelve, but we may be carrying on.
Go on.

Well, next week we're going to try and do another one to continue this for at least a little while. We might have to charge a small fee for it because it'll cost us money and Carl is unemployed. But we mean a real tiny little fee. But hopefully we will be back next week. Now we're not sure where it'll be. It'll probably be on iTunes, but just go to rickygeves.com and we'll guide you there. Hurrah.
Yay.
And thanks for listening for this long and supporting us. I hope you continue to support. Go on, continue to support us.
Yeah. Particularly Carl, who has no money whatsoever and he's desperate. He's a desperate man.
There's no one out there going, oh, they're charging for it now. But you know, people forget we gave twelve for free.
This is it. So quickly people forget we're big shots.
Yeah, well, Carl's not, but, you know, we are, aren't we?
Exactly. I mean, yeah, we were generous, but we're not that generous.
We're not, we're not mad. And Karl needs a little bit of money. Look at his little round little head. He's like little tiny Tim over there.
Exactly.
Look at him sitting there. Carl, you've had a good week.
It's been all right.

Yeah, brilliant. Well, more of that next week, but you'll have to pay for it now. I'm surprised you're not buzzing because we just had our photograph taken to enter the Guinness Book of Records for the greatest downloaded podcast of all time. We went along to the Guardian and the press were there and they took a little picture of his roundhead, didn't they?
Yeah. Well, I don't know. Why should I be excited about it when it's just.
Have you always wanted to be in the Guinness world of records?
Not, not really, no.
I've got, I've been looking at the, they presented us with this year's and I've been looking through it and there's some fascinating ones I used to get.

That's what I'm saying, though. There's loads of things in there that I used to go to. Like I looked at it online the other day to see if you know what's on there, you click on it. The home page that you get when you click on Guinness Book of Records. It's a fellow with the most ear hair. Right. Looks amazing. So that, to me, is what the Guinness Booker records is about.
So you're impressed with the bloke who just happens to have the most ear hair.
No, but it's commitment. He could have. He could have shaved it off, but he didn't. He left it.
No, it's less commitment.
But we. Yeah, that just grew. We actually bothered to do a podcast.

I forget that. Then the one with the rings on the neck, where they stretch the neck so their head's tall, that's commitment. If that didn't work out, he's stuck with that head and he didn't even get in the book.
You're stuck with that head and you have got in the book, so be happy. What if he's a stitcher? What if you're under roundest Ed?
I'd be a bit annoyed.
Why?

Just because I don't. I mean, have you got a choice? Say, like the fella with, you know, the small man, say if he's. He's not happy about being small, he's trying to go about his life. He knows people are looking at him, pointing at him, going, look at him, he's tiny. But does he want to be in the book?
Oh, I think. I think they've got to give their consent.
Have they?
Because if the smallest wasn't willing to be in there, they'd go, the second smallest man is so and so. He was willing to be in here.
Yeah, but the smallest one is Frank, and he didn't want to do it. So again, he's in it without wanting to be in it.
He's got you there, Rick.

I don't know if they do, I don't know if they go around. I- I think that you'd have to be complicit in it for them to measure your head and say, this is the roundest head on the planet Earth. Not. You know what I mean?
But then what do I do with that? That's what I'm saying. Is it something you put on a cv? I don't see the point in it.

Well, I think you are the fellow with the roundest head, and I think a lot of people know that because also, I've noticed when people ask for a picture of you, they don't say, can I have a signed picture of Karl? They say, can I have a signed picture of Karl's head? Which is a weird thing to say about a human being, isn't it? They go, oh, look at his head. Look at his head. Not look at his face. Or, can I have a picture of him? They say, can I have a picture of. Have you got a picture of Karl's head? Why are they allowed to mention that?
And the thing is, like, we're on some sort of broadcasting medium where you don't even see me 'ead so it's not important.
Well, I can't see your head because the mic's perfectly round and it obliterates it out like an eclipse.
But what I mean is, it doesn't matter, does it, for doing what I do? It doesn't. It doesn't interfere in any shape or form.
The thing is, Karl, what people fascinate with, and I've said it before, you've got a head like a fucking orange.
Steve laughs

We'll be charging for more information like that from next week. We do, of course, Rick, every week get. Get thousands of emails. I mean, it's crazy. It takes us ages to go through them and read them. And we are. We are going through them. We are reading them. Freddie Gerstrom from Winchester says, of course, it was recently Valentine's Day. What's the most romantic thing that you've done for Suzanne, Karl, that you can think of?
I don't really do all that Valentine's Day stuff. It's just the problem is if you do it once, they expect it every year.
Yeah.
That's the problem with Christmas and stuff innit? It's like it's become. That's what you do now, every year.
Every day, yeah.

So I prefer to just sort of wait, you know? I mean, and, you know, if I think of an idea or I know of something that she wants, I might get something, but I might not do it on Valentine's Day. It's that thing. It's like I've said about pancake Tuesday. Make it pancake Wednesday, have it when you want. Why am I waiting? Why am I waiting for someone to tell me when I can have a pancake? I'll have it today if I want one. Know? I mean, there's pancake Tuesday. No, I won't bother. I'll have trifle. So. So it's the same. Same with this, you know, with Suzanne, luckily, right? I mean, Valentine's Day and what have you. She was. She was ill-
Luckily?
So we didn't... We didn't have to go out. So I'd say. Is he asking for advice?
Well, I suppose, yeah. Certainly. May as well give it.
Treat them when they deserve it.
I remember once when Suzanne was ill. She had a fever, but there was no food in the house. What did you suggest to her? She was too ill...?

Well, it was. It was when we were still living in Manchester and that, and, you know, we needed to get some food in for tea and stuff. And I said, come on, come to the supermarket. She's like, no, I'm ill. You go. And I hate buying food. I just sort of get a bit blank when I'm looking at this. Too much, isn't it? That's the problem. You go down all these aisles and it's just too much. So anyway, I said, no, come on, come with me. She was like, oh, but I've got this fever. I'm hot and everything. So I said, well, come to the supermarket. You go on the frozen aisle, cool yourself down. And she did. And she said, you know, it made it worse. She was ill for another three days.
How would you go about chatting up a woman in a bar? What tips could you give?
Um... I've never, I've never worked like that. It's always been like a friend of a friend and all that, and just happened to meet them. And then, you know, you have a chat and then-
How did you meet Suzanne?
Uh, that was when I was working with her. And she gave me 20p for the hot chocolate machine. She never asked for it back. I thought, "she's alright". Been, uh... sort of, eleven years. So it works.
You've never given that 20p back?
She never asked for it back.
Did you return the favour, perhaps on the next date? You buy her a KitKat or something?

No, I don't think I did. I think, I think word got out that she liked me and that. And uh... what did I do? I think I did some work for her, did some editing for her. Sort of show off me skills and that.
Sure.
And she was like, "oh, you're good at this, aren't you?" I was like, "yeah". And I think she got us another drink because I was, I was doing that editing for her in me own time.
So you're up. You're up on the deal, aren't you? Because I know now for a fact that you've not spent any money on her in eleven years. So you are, you're 40p up.
At least.

Lawrence from New York says, "I was wondering how Mr. K. Dilkington would interpret this famous saying of philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein. The quote is, "if a lion could talk, we could not understand him."
Even if he's English?

Yeah, if he... yeah. If a lion could speak English, so, there's no language barrier, he's speaking English words and using all the correct grammar and everything, but you wouldn't be able to understand what he was saying.
Why?

Because it is from a different world. His frames of reference would be so bizarre that you wouldn't be able to get a grasp on what he was talking about, because you'd have so little in common. Even if he used real words.
No, but he's talking English...
Yeah, I know, but his reference points would be just so far removed. You know, they're removed slightly when, uh... if you saw two people talking about Kierkegaard, you'd-
I wouldn't understand it.
Exactly. So remove that a billion times to a different species with different input.
No, but it depends, if I'm talking to a lion in London Zoo...
Yeah.

He'll be saying, "I'm fed up of being stuck in here", I'll go "yeah". It depends what his background is. I mean, there's some people who might have lived down the road from me but have a totally different life.
Absolutely.
So it doesn't matter it's a lion. Does it?
Well, yeah, because they're just trying to remove it even more. So now it's not just a bloke who lived a few doors away, now it's not even a bloke. Now it's not even-
Yeah, but I'd pick something smaller, or something, you know, a worm without a mouth. I'd go, "definitely not".
What?
Definitely not what?
I wouldn't be having a chat with it. I just, I just think that a worm that's underground...
Yeah.

What's it got to offer me? It's blind and it hasn't got a mouth. It's not going to be a good day out with it, is what I'm saying. It's not going to have that much to say to me. Even if it's English. Right?
Even if it's English!
And how can you tell if a worm is English? Does it wear a very tiny bowler hat?
Oh, christ.
But do you understand-
What about jellyfish?
No I- you see, I think that's where you can- you can say you wouldn't be able to have a good chat with them. Because, to me, the sea might as well be another world.
Yeah.
Right?
Yeah.
In a way, I think the fish sort of... have more rights than us.
What do you mean?
Just because, when- when whoever made the world, right? Say- you know, we were just bigging up God. But if it was- was to have a go at him,
Yeah.
I'd say: "You added too much water."
Ricky laughs
Criticism one, to God. Right.
Right? So- but because-
You- how would you have changed that? Just...
Just more land.
Fair enough. Now, why- why do the- why have fish got more rights than us? That's what I was interested in.

Because- because- because there's loads of them. And when you look at the amount of sea on the world, right? There's- there's loads of that. You only have to, like- Like, you know, I was in Málaga the other week, right? And, you know, you look in the sea, there's loads of different fish. And that's just in, like, eight-foot water. If you go miles out, there's, like, all sorts of weird fish, 'int there? With, like, lights on them and everything. So- and there's just millions of different types.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Now-
But why does that mean they've got more rights than us?

Just because I think what- you know, rights come in numbers, don't they? If you know what I mean. Like, if there's one of you shouting, people go: "Oh, he's an idiot. Shut up." Whatever. If there's loads of you shouting, they go: "Oh, best listen to them, see what they've got to say."
Right?
And that's what I mean about fish.
Steve chuckles
Yeah.
There's loads of fish.
Right?
So-
But they're not really making their voices heard, though, are they, Karl?
Yeah.
I know. Cause they're underwater. But what- but what I mean is... I don't know what I mean.
Ricky and Steve burst
The Ricky Gervais show on Guardian Unlimited.

Oh, pleased to meet you, start me up. I'm here to tell you all about Channel 4 Friday Night Comedy. So, start me up. Now then! There's three great new comedies, from new Green Wing - that's nearly ready - My Name is Earl, and the IT Crowd, the great new comedy from the creator of Father Ted. Ow! Friday Night Comedy, this Friday on Channel 4. Switch me in. It's gonna be a winner.
Intermission end

Karl, right? What- what do you think it's like being a crab? If you- if you could go now, your mind into a crab, what would you see? Where would you be? What would you be doing? What would you be thinking? What do you think of all the other things the crab should see? The- the squids you'd see. What- what's it like, do you think? I want you to- it's like creative writing; Just think, just let yourself go. Go on.
Uh, it's gotta be a crab?

What do you think of a slug? What do you think to be a slug? What would you do if you, if you were transported now into a slug, what would you do? And you and Suzanne, you're suddenly in the kitchen, but you're a slug. And Suzanne's sort of like there just making tea and that. How do you let her know it's you?
It's impossible. I'd just chuck myself into the salt pot or something. No, because what do you do? I'd hate that. That would be horrible, that.
Have you ever read Franz Kafka's "Metamorphosis"? In which a man wakes up and he's turned into a giant beetle? And that's the, that's the whole story. I think it might be of interest to you.
So what happened to him with the beetle?
Well, I don't want to ruin it for you in case you read it.
No, I won't be reading it, don't worry.
He joined a pop group with three other people, he was brilliant.

No, it's a really wonderful book. It's a kind of almost heartbreaking, because, of course he, he does, like Ricky's saying, find it very hard then to relate to other people, even though he still has the consciousness of a human. You know, his parents, the rest of his family—they don't know how to deal with him, you know, because he's a giant beetle. He becomes a freak; he becomes an outsider. It's terrible.

But hang on, though. Is he a giant beetle or is he-? Well, yeah. Well, that's not going to go down well, is it? That's - of course people aren't going to like you. But if it's a normal sized one, then you just get in with the other beetles, don't you? Whereas if you're a giant...

How would you do that? How would you ingratiate yourself? Right, so you're suddenly a beetle. You're Karl Pilkington, right? There's other people, they're doing their business, they're scuttling around. And you go in there and they look at you as a new beetle. What's your first - what do you do? How do you ingratiate yourself?

Well, for a bit, I wouldn't sort of barge in into their house and that. I'd wait until they're out and about and I'd, like in life, right, sort of help them out. I don't know what beetles do all day. I've never seen one doing anything, they just seem to be going from one place to another. I've never seen them carrying anything, I don't know what they eat. I don't know what they do. I don't know why we've got them, right? But what I mean is, I'd watch them and I'd sort of help them out. And I mean, you know, it's like going on a date or meeting a woman, isn't it?
But what if you-
Whoa, hang on, what do you mean, how is it like going on a date with a woman?
Well, it's like I said about Suzanne with her hot chocolate. She bought me that. And I've gone, "she's alright". Right? She gets me another one. Before I know it, she's living with me. So, it's -

So you're with these beetles, they're scrabbling around, right? You're sort of like watching them. And then you realise that you want to mate with this female beetle. What do you do? What's your first move?
Yeah, but I don't know what beetles do, do I? So I don't know how - what you do. I don't know if you go up and go "alright?". What do they do? How do they get on?
It's a different world. I don't know yet, do I? Because I haven't done it.
Would you feel bad, because having your own mind in this beetle, right? Would you feel bad shagging a beetle? Would you feel that that was, that was a bit sick, because you've got a human mind?

Well, no, because you just close your eyes and that, wouldn't you? And go "I'll pretend to think of something else". So, get round it that way. There's no point getting down about it because I'm stuck now as a beetle, so you've got to get on with it.

But if you slug. You said you'd throw yourself in the soap pot. What you do if you beat or if you got depressed and you see all the other humans, you see your mates, right, they got. They're listening to the ipod, what would you do?
No, that's what I'm saying, though. Beetles are different because they do tend to hang about with each other. A slug's always on its own. It's a lonely insect, isn't it?
It's not an insect.
All right, what is it? Right, they're lonely. I've never seen a load of snails altogether or slugs wandering about as beetles seem to knock about in crowds.
Yeah.
So. Oh, God. Okay, right, another one.

So there are sociable creatures and it wouldn't bother you that you're. You've got the mind of Carl Pilkington in there, because you can't communicate with these people. They don't speak English. They don't. They have any communication with you.
Yeah, but if it's happened to me, there'll be another one in there.

Okay, then. Right. Okay. What would you do? Right. Disgusting thing. What could it be? Um, what what would you do, right, if you were suddenly a fly, right? And you knocking around with the flies, right, and you had to land on some, uh, excrement. Yeah. What would you do?
Yeah, but I don't have to.
What do you mean? You're a fly? Yeah.
I wouldn't know. I wouldn't be loving it there, would I?
Why?

Because I'm me in that fly's head. So I just. I don't think other flies would be going, come on, join in. I'd just be like, no, what? Wait here. What? Wait, watching that. Because they don't. I don't see why they have to do that.

What would you do, right, if you had to go back in your inner. You were, at degree, put your mind in like an unhatched egg of something, like maybe one of those, like a wasp was injected in a spider, so you know you're in an egg, right, which is really uncomfortable in a spider. How would you feel about that, Carl? You're a baby wasp in the abdomen of a spider.
And I know everything that I know. Now I'm sat in there, yeah.
And now. Now I'm in a spider as a baby, as an unborn wasp. What the fuck am I doing here? What's going on?
I don't know what I'll do there. Probably try and sleep. There's nothing else to do, though, is there?
I just pray to God it never happens.
The Ricky Gervais show on Guardian Unlimited.
I don't believe that he's written it down.

Well, that's the jingle that signals it's time for more extracts from Carl's diary and we'll lunge straight into it. Wandered down Carnaby street. There was a happy homeless fella. I gave him one pound 50. I thought of a tongue twister after giving him the money. It goes, if you can't treat a cheerful tramp what sort of tramp can you treat?
It's good that fast.
If you can't treat a cheerful tramp, what sort of tramp can you treat?
Good, innit?
Good that. Yeah. You've got too much time on your hands, Carl.
Learnt some famous quotes to see if they are as good as my sayings. Number one: treat every day as if it's your last. Very famous saying. Now, is that something you do, Karl?

Um, but you know, my problem with that one is that if it was your last, you wouldn't want to be doing much. That's, that's the only problem I've got with that. I wouldn't want to, you know, go to a fairground or whatever, because you're going, oh, it's me last day. What am I going to do? And I think you'd spend so much time worrying about what you're going to do that you'd end up staying in.
I think you're right. You've taken some of the poetry out of it. I think it means live life to the fullest.
I like the fact that you were musing on the idea that if it was your last day, you'd go to the fair. It's such a 19th century way of spending your final day.

I know, yeah! Well, the thing is, the other thing is that the only thing that people get depressed about in terms of sort of like, you know, life and death is not the knowledge that they're gonna die, but more the knowledge that they know they're gonna die when they're dying. If someone told you, no one ever knows when they're gonna die. No one ever gets an illness. No one ever gets hit by a truck. Everyone passes away peacefully in their sleep dreaming they're riding a big marshmallow. Right? Then you wouldn't care about anything. It wouldn't matter when, it wouldn't matter if you died tomorrow or in 30 years time. You just live life to the full. You'd come, you'd, you'd have it, every day would be great. You'd go out, you'd come back, you'd fall asleep. That would be amazing. There'd be no stress. There'd be no, there'd be no angsty, we're all gonna die stress because it wouldn't matter. Because it would just be your life. Wouldn't it be amazing if someone guaranteed you, Karl, you're gonna die in your sleep. I'm not gonna tell you when.
Yeah but some people do, don't they?
Well, exactly. But we never know we're going to because we stress. What if we get a dreadful illness? What if we, you know.
But we're almost not letting people die naturally anymore, are we? 'Cause we're always bodging stuff up.
What do you mean?

Well, someone who might naturally die in their sleep aren't allowed to naturally die in their sleep because they wake them up with those electric things and get them going again and pop in a new lung or whatever whilst they're at it. That's what I'm saying. They don't just, you never hear it anymore, do you? Frank peacefully died in his sleep. No, he died on the operating table whilst we were putting in any new lung. They don't die naturally anymore.
Frank died peacefully with 40,000 volts going through them and a couple of people going "Clear!"

Rushing about today. Gotta get a lot done as I'm flying to Malaga tomorrow to see my mum and dad. Don't like flying. I'd be happy if they give you a parachute instead of a life jacket. They say da Vinci invented the parachute as well as the helicopter. He never got round to making them, though, cause he only drew them on some paper. Got up at 05:00 a.m. as I had to get to Heathrow to get on the plane to see mum and dad in Malaga. Went out for a drink with a cousin who lives in Spain. Ain't seen her for 27 years. Oh, that must have been tricky, making conversation.
I didn't really bother because where do you start? I might as well go up to anyone in the street and start having a chat.
You have to go further back than. Did you want Chantal to win big brother?

Yeah. My dad and me talked about history. I said we shouldn't go on about things that happened ages ago because I bet something similar has happened more recently. Brilliant read about an island in the Indian Ocean where there are tribesmen still living like their cavemen. A helicopter tried to land and the tribesmen chucked spears at them. This is what I meant about not having to talk about things that happened ages ago. We have got new cavemen now, so why do we talk about the old ones? People could have lived before, but computers and all that blew up and books got burnt, so all they had left was what these tribesmen have got left. Ramblings around, man of a maniac. I mean, that's just a few hours before you go crazy with a gun in there.
No, but what, what I mean, there is, right? Say if all this has happened before, right? Podcasting has been happening years ago, something happens again.
Lot of information from the planet of the apes.
Something happens, world ends. Right? We come back again somehow.

Yeah. It's the detail you leave out that makes you intriguing. Just like the watch that you can wear that tells you when you're gonna die. How does it work? Pop it on your wrist. That's all the detail you need. So the world happened, we came back. We.
Have you seen the pictures? Forget it then if you don't get it.

It's interesting that you had all those profound thoughts about this period into the past, when they all lived, but you've still found it appropriate to include at the end of that, it says, the tribesmen wave their knobs about when they've had enough of having visitors.
That's what's what it said in the paper. That's what happens. They quite.
What paper is this that you're reading?

It was in, like, a paper a couple of days ago. It said they don't mind having visitors if they're bringing them coconuts and stuff that they can eat. Once they've got everything they need, they start waving the tackle about. And that means, like, right, leave now. Which you would, wouldn't you?
Yeah, at a dinner party.
My grandfather used to do that.

Well, now, well, now, well, now, what have we here? I'm here to tell you all about Friday night comedy on Channel four. There's three great comedies. Green wing. It's nearly ready. My name is Earl and the IT crowd. The great new comedy from the creator of Father Ted. And what have we here? Jingle, jangle, jingle, jangle, as it happens, Friday night comedy this Friday on Channel four. Switch it on now then. Well, now, the old man.
Ugh.
Well, now, now then. Well, now, now then, young man.
That jingle is getting more annoyed by the week.
Well, this is the final monkey news, right? I'm not. I'm not doing this anymore. Right. Because we've. We've covered it all.
All the monkey news has been covered?
It has, it has. We've done, we've done loads of them. I think all the news that needs to be, sort of known, has been told. Right?
That is the end of the news. Jesus Christ.
What?
Get on with it.
Right, do you know, in the first podcast that we did, we chatted about the monkey that went into space and stuff. So where we left it-
So we haven't even got a real new monkey news?
Well, it's an update, innit? I mean-
Is it new? Has it happened recently? Has it happened since podcast one?
I have to pick Ricky up on the point that he thinks any of the monkey news we've heard A, happened and B, happened recently. It almost always happened "in olden times" or "ages ago."
Oh, you're right. It never happened.
Right, anyway. So like I say, the first monkey news, it was about this monkey that went into space.
This is the one that was fed by bananas that came out of a little shoot on the spacecraft.
Yeah, it went up there, did a really good job. It was taught how to press the buttons. Hit the left button for a banana, you know.
Right button to...
To go right.
Make history and go into space.
Right.

"Ooh, what do I want?" Not more banana. "You haven't taken off yet." More banana. "Oh, we shouldn't give him a choice of banana or change history, which is the right button. We should have fed him before he went and only had a right button. He's hit the left button again. He's just eating bananas up there! What's going on?"
It's costing us a fortune!
Little fucker. Press the right button and do summat! "I want bananas" He hit the left button again, the little fucker!
So anyway, yeah, I told you, he went up there, he came back. He could never get that-
The high he was after.

The high again, yeah. You know what I mean? He tried other things. I think he tried to get a band together and that. Right, so anyway, there was loads of monkeys that were signed up to this NASA programme. And it was 1961 when this little monkey called Ham, that was his name. So a bit of an update, that's, that's the same one as I talked about, his name was Ham. As well as him, there was one called Enos. He went round the world loads of times. So anyway, what I found out about it since then, Ham went up there, did the left-right business with the bananas. Enos, they didn't put as much work into the trip when, when he went up there and something went wrong with the machinery. And do you know how you get a banana for the left button and all that?
It's official now. There's two buttons in this spaceship: banana dispenser and everything else. The right button is everything else.
But it worked the other way. The machinery went weird.
Oh, no, really?
So it meant that the right button would give him a banana.
Right.
The left button did everything else.
Oh, no!
How did that, how did that happen?
So what he'd been taught, this is the problem with, with electronics innit?
Well, no, I don't see that it is.
Apparently this is the problem.
But the good. I mean, honestly, look it up if you want. This is all online, by the way.
So what happened when it all went haywire? What, what occurred?
Luckily-
Karl, Karl, this is online and it's bollocks!
Luckily, Enos, because he'd done a few trips.
Right.
So he was like, well, I know this isn't right. As much as I love bananas, this isn't right.
Steve cackles
So-
They're just thinking, "of course it was."
